[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-crypto/src/blstrs/mod.rs] [Function: g1_proj_from_bytes()] [Cofactor attack] Even with subgroup checking, can attackers exploit the cofactor of the BLS12-381 curve to create small-subgroup attacks that break aggregate signature security? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-crypto/src/blstrs/mod.rs] [Function: g2_proj_from_bytes()] [Subgroup check bypass] Can attackers provide G2 points in small subgroups that pass the is_some() check but break the discrete log assumption, allowing private key extraction from BLS signatures? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-crypto/src/blstrs/mod.rs] [Function: g2_proj_from_bytes()] [Invalid curve point] Does G2Projective::from_compressed validate that points lie on the correct twist of BLS12-381, or can attackers inject points on wrong curves to forge signatures? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-crypto/src/blstrs/mod.rs] [Function: g2_proj_from_bytes()] [G2 identity exploitation] Can the G2 identity element be exploited in signature schemes to create trivial signatures that pass verification, bypassing authentication in threshold signatures? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-crypto/src/blstrs/mod.rs] [Function: g2_proj_from_bytes()] [Twist security] Does the function properly validate twist points, or can attackers leverage invalid-curve attacks to break pairing-based cryptography in validator signature schemes? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-crypto/src/blstrs/mod.rs] [Function: g2_proj_from_bytes()] [Decompression timing] Does G2 decompression run in constant time, or can timing side-channels leak information about secret shares in threshold signature reconstruction? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-crypto/src/blstrs/mod.rs] [Function: g2_proj_from_bytes()] [Point malleability] Can the same G2 point have multiple valid compressed representations, allowing signature malleability that violates Aptos transaction uniqueness invariants? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-crypto/src/blstrs/mod.rs] [Function: g2_proj_from_bytes()] [Buffer overflow] Since G2_PROJ_NUM_BYTES is 96 bytes, can attackers provide byte slices just under 96 bytes that cause try_from to succeed but corrupt memory in subsequent operations? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-crypto/src/blstrs/mod.rs] [Function: g2_proj_from_bytes()] [Error propagation] Can DeserializationError be exploited to mask more serious errors like memory corruption, preventing proper error handling in signature verification? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-crypto/src/blstrs/mod.rs] [Function: scalar_from_bytes_le()] [Field overflow] Does Scalar::from_bytes_le properly reject scalars >= SCALAR_FIELD_ORDER, or can attackers inject invalid scalars that wrap around and break discrete log security? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-crypto/src/blstrs/mod.rs] [Function: scalar_from_bytes_le()] [Zero scalar attack] Can an all-zero byte array create a zero scalar that causes division-by-zero in Lagrange interpolation for threshold signature reconstruction? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-crypto/src/blstrs/mod.rs] [Function: scalar_from_bytes_le()] [Little-endian confusion] Can attackers exploit endianness confusion between this function and scalar_from_uniform_be_bytes to inject malformed scalars that corrupt cryptographic operations? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-crypto/src/blstrs/mod.rs] [Function: scalar_from_bytes_le()] [Constant-time violation] Does the is_some().unwrap_u8() check at line 138 leak timing information about scalar validity, allowing adaptive attacks on threshold signature shares? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-crypto/src/blstrs/mod.rs] [Function: scalar_from_bytes_le()] [Invalid scalar persistence] If None is returned from Scalar::from_bytes_le, can the DeserializationError be caught and bypassed to allow invalid scalars into the system? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-crypto/src/blstrs/mod.rs] [Function: scalar_from_bytes_le()] [Length validation bypass] Does try_from at line 132 properly validate exact 32-byte length, or can 31 or 33 byte inputs cause subtle validation bypasses? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-crypto/src/blstrs/mod.rs] [Function: multi_pairing()] [Pairing malleability] Can attackers provide G1/G2 points in different representations that produce identical pairings but different hashes, breaking signature uniqueness in consensus? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-crypto/src/blstrs/mod.rs] [Function: multi_pairing()] [Iterator length mismatch] If the lhs and rhs iterators have different lengths, does zip silently truncate causing incomplete pairing computations that accept invalid aggregate signatures? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-crypto/src/blstrs/mod.rs] [Function: multi_pairing()] [Memory exhaustion] Can attackers provide extremely long iterators to cause unbounded memory allocation in the Vec::collect operations, causing OOM crashes during signature verification? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-crypto/src/blstrs/mod.rs] [Function: multi_pairing()] [G2Prepared caching] Does G2Prepared::from conversion cache computed values, or can repeated conversions of the same G2 point leak timing information about signature verification? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-crypto/src/blstrs/mod.rs] [Function: multi_pairing()] [Affine conversion side-channel] Do the to_affine() conversions at line 153 execute in constant time, or can timing variations leak information about point coordinates in threshold signatures? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-crypto/src/blstrs/mod.rs] [Function: multi_pairing()] [Empty pairing] What happens if both iterators are empty - does multi_miller_loop return a valid but meaningless result that breaks signature verification logic? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-crypto/src/blstrs/mod.rs] [Function: multi_pairing()] [Intermediate vector allocation] Can the double collect() operations at lines 154-157 be exploited to cause quadratic memory complexity attacks when verifying large batches of signatures? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-crypto/src/blstrs/mod.rs] [Function: multi_pairing()] [Point at infinity in pairing] If either lhs or rhs contains the point at infinity, does the pairing correctly handle this edge case or can it be exploited to create trivial signature forgeries? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-crypto/src/blstrs/mod.rs] [Function: multi_pairing()] [Duplicate point handling] Can attackers provide duplicate G1 or G2 points in the iterators to manipulate pairing results and forge aggregate signatures in consensus? (High)
